reviewText: Battle plan breaks down key military strategies with contrasting examples.  Usually, they have a successful example and an unsuccessful one.  One example usually being post 1980 and another from around the WWII period.  They included thoughtful analysis from historical experts and used illustrations throughout.  While not quite on the same level as the 360 series, this is a very good dvd set.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I agree with most of the reviewers that this is a good introduction to military strategy, but it is going to far to include the two American wars with Iraq. True, they are interesting in and of themselves, but they can't be compared with World War II or Vietnam which were hard-fought campaigns, whereas there never was any doubt about the outcome of the Iraqi wars since Iraq never had a chance. The only question was whether the American-led coalition forces would be able to avoid casualties.I do take exceptions to some of the conclusions of some of the later episodes:(1) In "Pre-emptive Strike" Israel's Six-Day War is used as an outstanding example...however their conclusion that Israel didn't have an "exit strategy" is incorrect.  Israel stated at the time that it was willing to withdraw from all the territories in return for peace agreements with the Arab states involved. The Arabs refused and have not changed their position, with the exception of the Egyptians who did attain a full Israeli withdrawal.(2) In "Strategic Bombing" they take the popular view that RAF Air Chief Marshal Harris' policy (which he did not initiate, but which he inherited) of night-time area bombing of German cities was ineffectual. This was based on flawed analysis of the campaign done right after the war.  Recent studies, including extensive surveys of German civilians who had to endure it have shown that, on the contrary, it was very effective at destroying morale of the population and greatly reducing arms production over the levels that were planned at the time. True, it had been advertised that it might lead to a total collapse of the German war effort, and it did not achieve this, and in addition, Harris' "Battle of Berlin" in late 1943-early 1944 led to high casualties among the bomber crews and mixed results at best, but on the whole, the Allies achieved a considerable payback for the sacrifices they made at the time.(3)  In the "Flank Attack" episode it is stated that in the first American-Iraqi war General Schwartzkopf "failed" to close the gap on the fleeing Iraqi armies, in particularly , the elite Republican Guard, just as the British and Americans failed to close the Falaise Gap in the wake of the Normandy Landings, allowing a considerable number of German troops to escape to the east.This is simply incorrect-the Saudis who dictated the war's aims to the Americans who would do the fighting viewed the war as simply giving Saddam a slap on the wrist for invading Kuwait but they certainly did NOT want his regime to be destablized or overthrown, viewing him as a "bulwark" against the Iranian-Islamic threat. Thus, there never was any intention of closing the trap and Schwartzkopf carried out his orders as he was given them NOT to eradicate the Republican Guard.Having said this, I highly recommend the series.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an 18 episode series that looks at basic military strategies such as blitzkrieg, flank attacks and strategic bombing.  These are handled very simply, what is interesting is the historical examples (usually 2) given for each.  Those interested in military history will like this.  I was particularly impressed with the information given on the Son Tay POW camp raid in Vietnam, as I had known little about the actual raid, as well as the Nazi rescue of Mussolini.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a pleasure history buff.  I found this series to be a good companion to a history collection.  A delicious appetizer.  Excellent buy for the price for what I call "Infortaining". Both informative and entertaining in it's class.PROS:-Battle Tactics focused.-Comparisons of WW1, WW2 and recent battles "innovative".-Clear picture.-Excellent sound track.-Action oriented theme flavour.-Hollywood style doc film.-Fast pace.-Enthusiastic narrator.-CGI map illustration.CONS:-Generic military doc.-Comparing WW1 & WW2 to Gulf & Iraq war battles might be a far stretch.-Short on battle footage.-Elementary type of mapping.-Repetitive "to a point it's annoying".-British analyst has bad teeth "distracting".-American analyst "looks more like an actor, could be a fake".-Cheap DVD's. "2 sided".-Booklet companion is larger than DVD case causing it to bend and crumple.-Poor DVD case internal set up.-Oh and did I mention repetitive?Overall this is a good bargain.  I gave the 4th star for the price.  Better than watching American Idol!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you pick this item up used, it's 12 hours plus of really good entertainment/information for very little $. The computer graphics that explain the tactics are pretty cool and the narrator isn't annoying. A bargain and well worth picking up if you enjoy WWII documentaries like I do.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Watch this if you have absolutely no knowledge of military history...absolutely none. This series was just an excuse to repackage a lot of stock footage that has been shown in a lot of much better series.  The narrator is beyond annoying and the explanations so simplistic it is simply a waste of time & money. Anything topic discussed can be gleaned from a variety of much better sources.

reviewText: There seems to be two versions out. Mine has 5 double-sided DVD's with poor quality transfer, and poor quality DVD case (I have replaced). I noticed people having the single-sided DVD report good quality. Anyway, the contents is great, I recommend it. Just buy it from a reputable seller, not the low price-one, as I did.

reviewText: I recently purchased this DVD set "Battleplan: The Complete Series" here and it is pretty good stuff if you like WW2 documentary materials. I got this DVD set just fine and watched it the same day...it's pretty good.
